caption: Great place to relax, read a book, bask in the sun (in case there is some sun) and people watch.
This spot is great for relaxing, find an empty chair and enjoy.

This is the circular body of water at the southeast end of the Tuileries Gardens. It is located on a direct line from the counterpoint Octagonal Basin at the northwest end, connected by the Central Alley walk through the Gardens.  There are metal chairs places around the Round Basin if you want to take a seat and relax here. Expect to find quite a few others doing the same throughout the day. There is a small centre piece shooting water upwards and into the basin. You will also find monuments placed around the basin grounds and can enjoy sightseeing in pretty much any direction after taking a good little rest and walking break here.
Amazing to see the Olympic flame here during the 2024 games. Beautiful setting. Near quite a few metro stops as well.

Large fountain with a bunch of chairs to relax on while you observe the Louvre. It is also possible to see the Place de la Concorde (Obélisque de Louxor), with the faded silhouette of the Arc de Triomphe behind it, and even the top of the Eiffel Tower rising up from the hills. Great place to visit in the Tuileries Garden after visiting the Louvre.
Huge fountain with plenty of seating around it. Great location to relax on a sunny day and watch the birds.
If you need a place to relax in hectic Paris, this is it. There are more than enough chairs to find a place to sit.  Enjoy the ducks, enjoy the Parisians walking by, enjoy the day.
Had to see the Olympic vasque while it was still here. Hopefully they'll keep it forever
This was a very relaxing place to spend some time in the morning! I would definitely recommend if you’re in the Louvre area. The whole garden area is nice!
A place to relax and read a book in the company of several ducklings, on sunny days it feels great to be here.
A spectacular fountain to visit. Both for aesthetics and for the ability to relax on the provided chairs there.

Visit to the Olympic flame, very beautiful moment, very beautiful place, I strongly recommend going there! With reservations required, there are not too many people and you can enjoy the flame and take photos! The rise into the sky of the flame from 10 p.m. must also be an exceptional experience!

Jardin des Tuileries, often translated as Tuileries Garden, is a royal garden with a long history located in the center of Paris, France. Its history can be traced back to the end of the 16th century, when it was built as a private garden for the French royal family. Part of the banks of the Seine that was included in the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1991. The gardens were designed by Catherine de Medici in 1564 as the gardens of her residence, the Palais des Tuileries. Originally created primarily to decorate the Tuileries Palace, the gardens were carefully designed as a private space for the royal family, with gorgeous landscaping and elegant arrangements. At the end of the 17th century, Louis XIV decided to open the garden to the public, becoming the first royal garden in France open to the public. This decision not only allowed the public to enjoy this exquisite green space, but also marked an important turning point in the history of France. During the Paris Commune in 1871, the Tuileries Palace was razed to the ground by revolutionaries. The Tuileries Palace, which was burned down during the French Revolution, was not demolished until 1883, and the original site of the palace became part of the Tuileries Garden. The Tuileries Garden is located on the left bank of the Seine, adjacent to the Musée du Louvre. The gardens cover approximately 25 hectares and feature an elegant layout and rich historical heritage. The garden is planted with a variety of trees, flowers and sculptures, as well as open lawns and tranquil fountains. It is not only a good place for Parisians to take a leisurely walk, but also an excellent place to appreciate the French gardening style.
